results.title: Commercial sexual exploitation of children
results.creator_credit: ECPAT Australia, Gail Price and Nicholas Bird
results.brief_description: Discusses the global issue of commercial exploitation of children and the various forms this abuse can take, eg prostitution, slave-trade, pedophilia, internet pornography. Mentions some of the causes as being poverty, homelessness, consumerism, absence of child protection, cultural and traditional practices and a growing child sex tourist trade. Also talks about positive strategies that can be taken at all levels, local, regional, national and international. ECPAT is an international network of organisations committed to ending the commercial exploitation of children. Formed in 1991, ECPAT now reaches to over 50 countries globally and closely works with various government departments, such as Tourism and Child Welfare. Cast: Michael Brakensiek, Sarah Hill, Michael Williams, Afshin Nikousheresht. Narration: Patrick J. Bonello, Damian Nicholas.

results.title: Coming out under fire
results.creator_credit: Deepfocus Productions and Arthur E. Dong
results.brief_description: Based on the book of the same name by Allan Berube, who co-wrote the documentary, “Coming out under fire” interviews ten gays and lesbians who served in the military during the Second World War. Intercut with declassified military “education” films and newsreels, the interviews form a grave counterpoint to the campy, wholly ludicrious and sometimes painful stock footage where homosexuals were portrayed as darkly psychologically malevolent individuals. This entrenched homophobia resulted in anti-homosexual dragnets and entrapment schemes that caused great psychological distress to homosexuals within the military. The documentary is framed by the 1993 U.S. congressional hearings which resulted in the so-called “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy toward gays in the armed services, a policy which was calculated to please no-one and which was predicted to be a failure before it ever began, opening the gates once more on service-wide anti-homosexual entrapment schemes.

results.title: Coming home
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly, Colin Low and Bill Reid
results.brief_description: Here, in cinema verite style, film is used as a means of letting a family look in on itself, at the differences of outlook, lifestyle and values that separate the parents and two grown sons. Completely unrehearsed, it is a record on film, of a few days’ visit back home on the part of the older son (the filmmaker) and of the conversations that took place among the four in a genuine though abortive attempt to reach mutual understanding. The film is an example of the communications barrier that divides many families.

results.title: Coming home
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Jerome Hellman and Hal Ashby
results.brief_description: A lonely army wife (Jane Fonda), whose husband is serving in Vietnam, falls in love with a paralysed veteran (Jon Voight) she meets while working as a volunteer in the Army base hospital. An unusually mature examination of the effect of the Vietnam War on the lives of American servicemen. Winner of Academy Awards for Fonda and Voight. Based on a story by Nancy Dowd.

results.title: Comets and asteroids
results.brief_description: Many scientists believed that the Earth’s geology developed in isolation, unaffected by its neighbours in the solar system. Join Dr. Brady Barr as he explains the difference between comets and asteroids, and how these objects may offer clues as to the origins of our solar system. The theories and research of geologist Gene Shoemaker, co-discoverer of the Shoemaker-Levy 9 comet in 1993, are also explored in detail, particularly his efforts to prove that craters such as Arizona’s Barringer Crater and Germany’s Ries Basin were the impact sites of objects from space. Includes five assessment questions on the content of the video, plus a brief teacher’s guide.
